Diabetologia. 2003; 46: 365-377Crossref PubMed Scopus (250) Google Scholar), and was previously shown to eliminate PPARγ binding to PPREs (43Park Y. Freedman B.D. Lee E.J. Park S. Jameson J.L. Diabetologia. 2003; 46: 365-377Crossref PubMed Scopus (250) Google Scholar). The PPARγ-AA mutant was created by converting amino acids 157 and 158 from glutamate and glycine to alanine and alanine, respectively, and was previously shown to eliminate binding of estrogen receptor α to estrogen response elements (44Jakacka M. Ito M. Weiss J. Chien P-Y. Gehm B.D. Jameson J.L. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 13615-13621Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (239) Google Scholar). The PPARγ-CS mutant was created by converting amino acid 159 from cysteine to serine (45Chatterjee V.K. Lee J.K. Rentoumis A. Jameson J.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989; 86: 9114-9118Crossref PubMed Scopus (176) Google Scholar) and was designed to disrupt the physical structure of zinc finger I. For mammalian two-hybrid assays, PCR was performed on PPARγ-pKCR2 to obtain full-length PPARγ as a SalI/XbaI fragment. The SalI/XbaI PPARγ fragment was then inserted into the multiple cloning site of the pVP16 vector (Clontech, Palo Alto, CA). Mutations were subsequently made in the PPARγ-pVP16 construct using the QuikChange site-directed mutagenesis kit (Stratagene) to produce PPARγ-GS-, PPARγ-AA-, and PPARγ-CS-pVP16. The ligand-binding domain of RXRα was placed downstream of the DNA-binding domain of Gal4 in the vector pECE, as described previously (46Cohen R.N. Wondisford F.E. Hollenberg A.N. Mol. Endocrinol. 1998; 12: 1567-1581Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). A UAS-TK-luciferase reporter was made by placing five copies of a Gal4-binding site upstream of luciferase driven by a thymidine kinase promoter. Full-length human RXRα was inserted into the pKCR2 (pSG5) expression vector as an EcoRI fragment. Point mutations in the P-box region of RXR-pCKR2 were introduced using the QuikChange site-directed mutagenesis kit (Stratagene). The RXR-GS mutant was created by converting amino acids 153 and 154 from glutamate and glycine to glycine and serine, respectively. PPAR-responsive luciferase reporter constructs were created by inserting two copies of the respective PPREs into the Asp-718 and BglII sites of the pGL2-Promoter vector (Promega Corp., Madison, WI). PPRE-luciferase reporters constructed included: ACO-PPRE (AGGACAAAGGTCA), aP2-PPRE (GGATCAGAGTTCA), PEPCK-PPRE (CGGCCAAAGGTCA), ME-PPRE (GGGTCAAAGTTGA), 3′ Consensus ME-PPRE (GGGTCAAAGGTCA), 3′ mutant ACO-PPRE (AGGACAATTTTCA), 5′ (1) mutant ACO-PPRE (TTTACAAAGGTCA), 5′ (2) mutant ACO-PPRE (AGGTTTAAGGTCA), 5′ (1) PEPACO-PPRE (CGGACAAAGGTCA), and 5′ (2) PEPACO-PPRE (AGGCCAAAGGTCA). Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assays—Proteins for electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSA) were obtained by in vitro transcription and translation using the T7 TnT®-coupled reticulocyte lysate system (Promega Corp., Madison, WI). Translation using [35S]methionine (Invitrogen) was followed by SDS-PAGE analysis and visualization after autoradiography to assess the size of translated proteins and to verify that they are expressed as full-length proteins (see Fig. 1c). The upper strand oligonucleotides used for EMSAs are as follows: aP2-PPRE (5′-CATACTGGATCAGAGTTCATGTGTC-3′), ACO-PPRE (5′-AGTGGACCAGGACAAAGGTCACGTTCGGGA-3′), ME-PPRE (5′-CATTCTGGGTCAAAGTTGATCCCCT-3′), PEPCK-PPRE (5′-CACCCACGGCCAAAGGTCATGTGTC-3′), 3′ Consensus ME-PPRE (5′-CATTCTGGGTCAAAGGTCATCCCTT-3′), Inverted PEPCK-PPRE (5′-CACCCAAGGTCAACGGCCATGTGTC-3′), 5′ (1) mt PEPCK-PPRE (5′-CACCCATTTCCCAAAGGTCATGTGTC-3′), 5′ (2) mt PEPCK-PPRE (5′-CACCCACGGTTTAAGGTCATGTGTC-3′), and 3′ mt PEPCK-PPRE (5′-CACCCACGGCCAATTTTCATGTGTC-3′). In vitro translated proteins were preincubated with 3 × 106 cpm of 32P-labeled probe for 20 min at room temperature in 10 μl of binding buffer containing 20% glycerol, 20 mm HEPES, pH 7.6, 50–140 mm KCl, 1 mm dithiothreitol, 1 μg of poly(dI-dC), and 0.1 μg of salmon sperm. The protein-DNA complexes were resolved on 4% nondenaturing polyacrylamide gels with 0.5× TBE (0.045 m Tris-borate, 0.001 m EDTA) running buffer, and visualized after autoradiography. Cell Culture and Transient Transfection Assays—Human embryonic kidney (293T) cells were maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with l-glutamine, 10% fetal bovine serum, and antibiotic/antimycotic. Transient transfection studies were carried out in 6-well plates using Lipofectamine Plus™ (Invitrogen). 15–18 h after transfection, the cells were washed with phosphate-buffered saline and treated with Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium containing either vehicle (Me2SO) or 1 μm troglitazone. After 24 h of treatment with either vehicle or troglitazone, cells were harvested and assayed for luciferase activity using a Lumat LB 9507 Luminometer (Berthold Technologies, Oak Ridge, TN). Endocrinol. 1994; 8: 829-840PubMed Google Scholar, 43Park Y. Freedman B.D. Lee E.J. Park S. Jameson J.L. Diabetologia. 2003; 46: 365-377Crossref PubMed Scopus (250) Google Scholar, 44Jakacka M. Ito M. Weiss J. Chien P-Y. Gehm B.D. Jameson J.L. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 13615-13621Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (239) Google Scholar). To confirm this observation with PPARγ, in vitro binding capabilities of the various PPARγ mutants were assessed using electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSAs). As seen in Fig. 1C, mutations in the DBD of PPARγ did not affect its ability to be expressed and translated into a full-length protein. The three visible bands represent translation of both the PPARγ1 and PPARγ2 isoforms, as well as the phosphorylated and unphosphorylated states of both of these proteins. The ability of PPARγ, PPARγ-GS, PPARγ-AA, and PPARγ-CS to bind was examined on various DR1 elements, including the acyl-CoA oxidase (ACO), adipocyte-specific fatty acid transport protein (aP2), phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK), and malic enzyme (ME) native PPARγ response elements (PPREs) (see Fig. 1D). PPARγ, PPARγ-GS, PPARγ-AA, PPARγ-CS, and RXRα proteins were in vitro transcribed and translated and subsequently incubated with a 32P-labeled DR1 double-stranded oligonucleotide for EMSA. Results indicated that PPARγ, PPARγ-GS, and PPARγ-AA are capable of binding PPREs in the presence of RXR. Significant binding was seen on a consensus PPRE (data not shown), as well as native PPREs for ACO, aP2, PEPCK, and ME. PPARγ-CS was incapable of binding any PPREs in vitro (Fig. 2). The lack of binding seen with PPARγ-CS is likely due to the absence of an intact zinc finger I structure, which is caused by the inability of the protein to coordinate a zinc molecule as a direct result of the mutation in cysteine 159. Although there is visible binding of PPARγ, PPARγ-GS, and PPARγ-AA on PPREs in the presence of RXR, there does appear to be a difference in binding affinities between the proteins on the various response elements. On the ACO-PPRE, PPARγ-GS binding is greater than that of either PPARγ or PPARγ-AA. Binding affinities of PPARγ, PPARγ-GS, and PPARγ-AA appear similar on the aP2-PPRE. For both the PEPCK- and ME-PPREs, binding of PPARγ-GS is significantly less than that of both PPARγ and PPARγ-AA. The variations seen in binding affinities of the PPARγ mutants prompted a thorough examination of their transcriptional capabilities on PPREs. DNA-binding Mutants of PPARγ Are Functional in Transfection Assays—Although the mutations in PPARγ-GS, PPARγ-AA, and PPARγ-CS were limited to the DBD, it is possible that the presence of these mutations may have affected the overall structure of the protein. If an alteration in the tertiary structure of the protein did occur as a result of the mutation in the DBD and subsequently affected its ability to heterodimerize with RXR, transcriptional activity could be altered as a result of a difference in heterodimerization capability rather than the inability of PPARγ to bind DNA. To ensure that PPARγ, PPARγ-GS, PPARγ-AA, and PPARγ-CS can heterodimerize with RXR in a similar manner, a mammalian two-hybrid assay was done with RXR and the PPARγ DNA-binding mutants. For this, full-length PPARγ was inserted into the pVP16 vector, and mutations were made to produce PPARγ-GS-, PPARγ-AA-, and PPARγ-CS-pVP16. RXR was placed downstream of the DBD of Gal4 in the vector pECE, as described previously (46Cohen R.N. Wondisford F.E. Hollenberg A.N. Mol. Endocrinol. 1998; 12: 1567-1581Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). Transient transfection assays using a UAS-TK-luciferase reporter were done in human embryonic kidney (293T) cells followed by treatment with 1 μm troglitazone for 24 h. Measurement of luciferase activity following troglitazone treatment clearly showed that there is no difference in the ability of PPARγ, PPARγ-GS, PPARγ-AA, and PPARγ-CS to heterodimerize with RXR (Fig. 3A). To assess whether PPARγ DNA-binding mutants can activate transcription, two copies of the ACO, aP2, ME, and PEPCK PPREs were each cloned into the pGL2-vector, and luciferase assays were subsequently done using all of the PPARγ constructs. Transient transfection assays were carried out in human embryonic kidney (293T) cells, followed by treatment with either vehicle or 1 μm troglitazone for 24 h. On the ACO-PPRE, transfection of PPARγ increased luciferase levels ∼10-fold over baseline, and there was no dependence on exogenous RXRα for this effect to occur (Fig. 3B), perhaps due to endogenous RXR in these cells. PPARγ-AA exhibited a transcriptional function similar to that of wild-type PPARγ. PPARγ-GS, however, was dependent on the transfection of exogenous RXRα for transcriptional activity, and then showed an activity that was 15-fold over baseline and 1.5-fold greater than wild-type PPARγ. PPARγ-CS had no transcriptional activity over empty vector alone, confirming its inability to bind DNA as seen in EMSA (Fig. 2) and indicating that transcriptional function of PPARγ requires DNA binding on the ACO-PPRE. The overall pattern of transcriptional function on the aP2-PPRE was similar to that of the ACO-PPRE, with PPARγ-GS being dependent on the transfection of exogenous RXRα, and PPARγ-CS being transcriptionally inactive. With the PEPCK-PPRE and the ME-PPRE, there was a different pattern to the transcriptional function of PPARγ and its mutants. Although wild-type PPARγ exhibited a transcriptional activity on the PEPCK-PPRE that was 9-fold higher than baseline with no dependence on exogenous RXRα, PPARγ-GS and PPARγ-AA had much lower transcriptional activity on the PEPCK-PPRE (5-fold and 4-fold, respectively), with PPARγ-GS still having some dependence on exogenous RXRα. The potato cDNAs Solanum tuberosum isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenases 1 and 2 (St-IVD1 and St-IVD2) encode proteins that are 84% identical to each other and 65 and 64% identical to human IVD, respectively. St-IVD2 protein was previously partially purified from potato tubers and confirmed to be an IVD. The function of St-IVD1 is unknown. In these experiments, both proteins were expressed in Escherichia coli and purified as intact homotetramers. The substrate preference profile of the St-IVD2 protein was similar to that of human IVD. However, recombinant St-IVD1 had maximal activity with 2-methylbutyryl-CoA, which in humans is dehydrogenated by short/branched-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (SBCAD). Whereas molecular modeling predicts that the 2-methylbutyryl-CoA dehydrogenase (2MBCD) and IVD substrate binding pockets are nearly identical, 2MBCD has amino acid substitutions at five residues that are invariant among all of the known and putative IVDs. Site-directed mutagenesis was used to match the human IVD active site with that of potato 2MBCD. The resulting mutant IVD had detectable activity with 2-methylbutyryl-CoA and no activity with isovaleryl-CoA. The 2MBCD active site was compared with that of human SBCAD using molecular modeling. Residues Met-361 and Ala-365 of 2MBCD appear to partially substitute for the function of Tyr-380 in human SBCAD, binding the methyl branch linked to C2 of 2-methylbutyryl-CoA, whereas residues Val-88, Val-92, and Val-96 appear to bind the distal C4 methyl group. The presence of a 2MBCD in potato that is highly homologous to IVD is an example of convergent evolution within the acyl-CoA dehydrogenase family, leading to the independent occurrence of two enzymes (SBCAD and 2MBCD) specific for 2-methylbutyryl-CoA. The presence of a 2MBCD in potato that is highly homologous to IVD is an example of convergent evolution within the acyl-CoA dehydrogenase family, leading to the independent occurrence of two enzymes (SBCAD and 2MBCD) specific for 2-methylbutyryl-CoA. Isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase (IVD 1The abbreviations used are: IVD, isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase; SBCAD, short/branched-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase; ETF, electron-transferring flavoprotein; ACD, acyl-CoA dehydrogenase; 2MBCD, 2-methylbutyryl-CoA dehydrogenase.; EC 1.3.99.10) and short/branched-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (SBCAD; EC 1.3.99.12) catalyze the α,β-dehydrogenation of isovaleryl-CoA and 2-methylbutyryl-CoA, respectively. The reduced enzymes, in complex with substrate/product, transfer electrons to the electron-transferring flavoprotein (ETF), which in turn passes them into the electron transport chain. Wolff J.A. Vockley J. Pediatrics. 2003; 112: 74-78Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar). SBCAD and IVD belong to the evolutionarily conserved acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (ACD) family of mitochondrial flavoenzymes, which share a 30–35% amino acid sequence homology. There are currently nine known ACD family members with distinct substrate specificity profiles. Short-chain, medium-chain, long-chain, and very long-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenases as well as the newest family member, ACD9, are involved in mitochondrial β-oxidation of fatty acids (7Eaton S. Bartlett K. Pourfarzam M. Biochem. J. 1996; 320: 345-357Crossref PubMed Scopus (351) Google Scholar, 8Zhang J. Zhang W. Zou D. Chen G. Wan T. Zhang M. Cao X. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2002; 297: 1033-1042Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar). In addition to IVD and SBCAD, two other ACDs are involved in branched-chain amino acid degradation. Isobutyryl-CoA dehydrogenase dehydrogenates an intermediate in valine degradation (9Nguyen T.V. Andresen B.S. Corydon T.J. Abd-El Ghisla S. Razik N. Mohsen A.W. Cederbaum S.D. Roe D.S. Roe C.R. Lench N.J. Vockley J. Mol. Genet. Metab. 2002; 77: 68-79Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar), whereas glutaryl-CoA dehydrogenase catalyzes both the dehydrogenation and decarboxylation of an intermediate in lysine degradation (10Fu Z. Wang M. Paschke R. Rao K.S. Frerman F.E. Kim J.J. Biochemistry. 2004; 43: 9674-9684Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). The ACDs are active in the mitochondrial matrix as homotetramers with the exception of very long-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase, which is a membrane-associated homodimer (11Kim J.J. Miura R. Eur. J. Biochem. 2004; 271: 483-493Crossref PubMed Scopus (152) Google Scholar). Based on the homology to very long-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase, ACD9 is thought to be a membrane-associated homodimer as well. Although mitochondrial ACDs involved in β-oxidation of fatty acids have not been identified in plants, cDNA sequences highly homologous to human IVD have been found in several plant species including Solanum tuberosum (potato), Arabidopsis, barley, corn, pea, rice, soy bean, and wheat. IVDs have been partially purified from potato and Arabidopsis and confirmed to have maximal enzyme activity with isovaleryl-CoA (12Daschner K. Couee I. Binder S. Plant Physiol. 2001; 126: 601-612Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar, 13Faivre-Nitschke S.E. Couee I. Vermel M. Grienenberger J.M. Gualberto J.M. Eur. J. Biochem. 2001; 268: 1332-1339Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar). Potato and Arabidopsis IVDs are unusual in that they were reported to be homodimers, and both appeared to have significant enzyme activity with isobutyryl-CoA, which is not used as substrate by either mammalian or Caenorhabditis elegans IVDs. Potato IVD is encoded by the St-IVD2 gene (GenBank™ accession number AJ278988). Another potato cDNA has been reported (St-IVD1, GenBank™ accession AJ278987) that translates into a predicted IVD-like protein that is 84% identical to the St-IVD2 gene product. However, the St-IVD1 gene product differs from >30 known and putative IVD sequences from a diverse range of species at five residues in the substrate binding pocket (14Mohsen A.W. Navarette B. Vockley J. Mol. Genet. Metab. 2001; 73: 126-137Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). This finding suggests that the St-IVD1 gene product might utilize substrates other than isovaleryl-CoA. To determine the function of St-IVD1, the St-IVD1 and St-IVD2 cDNAs were cloned from potato sprouts and expressed in Escherichia coli. Substrate specificity and biochemical parameters of the purified recombinant enzymes were determined. The importance of residues in the active site in determining substrate specificity was studied by remodeling the acyl binding pocket of human IVD to mimic that of the St-IVD1 gene product. Cloning of St-IVD1 and St-IVD2 cDNAs and Construction of Expression Vectors—A potato sprout weighing ∼300 mg was placed in liquid nitrogen in a mortar and pulverized with a pestle. The pulverized tissue was resuspended in 2 ml of TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen), and total RNA extraction was carried out following the manufacturer's instructions. First strand cDNA was synthesized using the iScript kit (Bio-Rad) from 1 μg of total potato RNA. The St-IVD1 and St-IVD2 coding regions minus the mitochondrial leader peptide sequences were then amplified with the Advantage High Fidelity-2 PCR kit (BD Biosciences) and TA-cloned into the pGEM-T Easy vector following the manufacturer's instructions (Promega, Madison, WI). The 5′-primer for St-IVD1 was designed to add a translation initiation codon just before the mature N terminus as well as an NdeI restriction site. Nucleotides were altered such that the first 17 amino acids reflected E. coli codon bias (15de Boer H.A. Kastelein R.A. Reznikoff W. Gold L. Maximizing Gene Expression. Butterworth Publishers, Stoneham, MA1986: 225-285Google Scholar, 16Mohsen A.W. Vockley J. Gene (Amst.). 1995; 160: 263-267Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). The primer was as follows, with the start codon in boldface and the changed nucleotides underlined:5′-TTC GAT TGT GCC AGA CAT ATG TCT ACT TCT TTA CTG CTG GAT GAT ACT CAG AAA CAG TTC AAA GAA AGT GTA-3′. The 3′-primer for St-IVD1 contained a PstI restriction site (5′-GCT GAC CTG CAG TTA TTG ATG TTT AAA GAG CTC ACG ACC-3′). St-IVD1 was subcloned from pGEM-T Easy into the pLEX prokaryotic expression vector (Invitrogen) using NdeI and PstI. The St-IVD2 expression plasmid was generated in a similar fashion. The 5′-primer contained an EcoRI restriction site and changed the first 12 amino acids to reflect E. coli codon bias. This primer was as follows, with the start codon in boldface and changed nucleotides underlined: 5′-GTG CCA GAA TTC ATG TCC ACT TCC CTG CTG TTC GAC GAC ACT CAG AAA CAG-3′. The 3′-primer contained a PstI site (5′-GCT GAC CTG CAG TCA TTG TTC TTT AAA GAG TTC ACG GCC-3′). The St-IVD2 PCR product was subcloned from pGEM-T Easy into the EcoRI and PstI sites of the pKK223–3 expression plasmid (Amersham Biosciences). All of the clones were sequenced in their entirety to confirm the lack of amplification errors. Expression and Purification of Recombinant Potato Enzymes—Expression of the St-IVD1 cDNA was performed with the PL expression system following the manufacturer's instructions (Invitrogen). Cells were grown in 10 liters of minimal medium at 30 °C to an A550 of 0.5. The expression of St-IVD1 was then induced with the addition of tryptophan to a final concentration of 100 μg/ml. After 3 h, the cells were harvested. The expression of St-IVD2 was performed as described previously for human IVD (16Mohsen A.W. Vockley J. Gene (Amst.). 1995; 160: 263-267Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar, 17Mohsen A.W. Vockley J. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 10146-10152Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar) in E. coli strain XL1Blue (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA). Both potato proteins were purified following the protocol previously developed for human IVD (16Mohsen A.W. Vockley J. Gene (Amst.). 1995; 160: 263-267Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar, 17Mohsen A.W. Vockley J. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 10146-10152Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar). Cells were disrupted by sonication, and cellular debris was removed by centrifugation. Crude cellular lysate was subjected to chromatography on DEAE-Sepharose Fast Flow (Amersham Biosciences) followed by chromatography on a 20-μm ceramic hydroxyapatite column (Bio-Rad). Purity was judged by SDS-PAGE. Both proteins were evaluated for the presence of bound CoA-persulfide, in common with recombinant IVDs, through spectral scans using a Beckman DU7400 spectrophotometer. Bound CoA-persulfide results in a shift of the absorbance peak in the 445-nm region along with an increase in absorbance centered around 550 nm (18Williamson G. Engel P.C. Mizzer J.P. Thorpe C. Massey V. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 4314-4320Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). CoA-persulfide was found only in the purified St-IVD2 gene product and was removed by treatment with sodium hydrosulfite (“degreening”) as described previously (14Mohsen A.W. Navarette B. Vockley J. Mol. Genet. Metab. 2001; 73: 126-137Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). Protein concentration of the purified samples was determined with the Bio-Rad protein assay reagent according to the manufacturer's instructions (Bio-Rad). Samples were stored in 20% glycerol at -80 °C until time of use. Construction and Expression of Mutant Human IVDs—PCR-based site-directed mutagenesis was used to introduce five mutations into the human IVD pKK223–3 expression construct that has been described previously (16Mohsen A.W. Vockley J. Gene (Amst.). 1995; 160: 263-267Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). L95V, A99V, and L103V substitutions were introduced with the following primer (with altered nucleotides underlined): 5′-GAG GAG ATA TCC CGA GCT TCC GGA GCA GTG GGG GTT AGT TAC GGT GTG CAC TCC AAC GTA TGC ATC AAC CAG CTT GTA CGC-3′. Following sequencing to verify the presence of the triple mutation, the L370M and G374A substitutions were introduced using the following primer: 5′-GAC TTT CCC ATG GGC CGC TTT CTT CGA GAT GCC AAG ATG TAT GAG ATA GCT GCT GGT ACC AGC GAG GTG AGG CG-3′. The altered nucleotides are underlined, and the italicized base pair was altered to introduce a KpnI restriction site without changing the amino acid sequence. The resulting quintuple mutant was sequenced to verify the presence of the mutations and the absence of other errors introduced by amplification. The double mutant L370M/G374A was generated from the quintuple mutant by subcloning a C-terminal fragment containing the desired mutations back into the wild-type IVD construct. Wild-type human IVD and the double, triple, and quintuple mutants were expressed in the JM105 strain of E. coli. For each mutant-expressing strain, a 50-ml culture was grown at 37 °C to an A550 of 0.8 and then induced with 0.5 mm isopropyl 1-thio-β-d-galactopyranoside for 20 h. Crude cellular extracts were prepared by sonication and centrifugation and assayed for enzyme activity. Enzyme Assays—Enzyme activity was measured with the anaerobic ETF fluorescence reduction assay using an LS50B fluorescence spectrophotometer from PerkinElmer Life Sciences with a heated cuvette block set to 32 °C as described previously (17Mohsen A.W. Vockley J. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 10146-10152Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar, 19Beckmann J.D. Frerman F.E. Biochemistry. 1985; 24: 3922-3925Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). Butyryl-CoA, valeryl-CoA, hexanoyl-CoA, octanoyl-CoA, isobutyryl-CoA, and isovaleryl-CoA were purchased from Sigma. (S)-2-Methylbutyryl-CoA was synthesized as described previously (20Binzak B. Willard J. Vockley J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1998; 1382: 137-142Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). One milliunit of activity is defined as the amount of enzyme necessary to completely reduce 1 nmol of ETF in 1 min. For kinetic analysis, ETF concentration was 1 μm and the substrate concentration was varied from 0.1 to 50 μm. The K m and Vmax values were calculated using the Psi Plot software, version 7.01 (Poly Software International, Pearl River, NY). Estimation of Molecular Mass—The molecular mass of the purified St-IVD1 and St-IVD2 gene products was estimated by gel filtration with a BioSep SEC-S3000 column (Phenomenex, Torrance, CA) on a Waters high pressure liquid chromatography system (Milford, MA). A standard curve for this column was generated using standards purchased from Amersham Biosciences as follows: ribonuclease A (13.7 kDa); ovalbumin (43 kDa); albumin (67 kDa); aldolase (158 kDa); catalase (232 kDa); and ferritin (440 kDa). Running buffer was 20 mm KPO4, 150 mm NaCl, pH 7.0, flowed at a rate of 1.0 ml/min. Approximately 50 μg of St-IVD1 or St-IVD2 gene products were injected onto the column. Approximately 50 μg of human IVD was injected as a control. The elution volume for each protein was determined by following the absorbance at 280 nm using a Waters 996 photodiode array detector. The molecular mass of recombinant human IVD, St-IVD2, and Arabidopsis IVD was also estimated from E. coli crude cellular extracts separated with a Superdex™ 200 size-exclusion column on a ÅKTA fast protein liquid chromatography unit (Amersham Biosciences). Crude cellular extracts from 10 ml of E. coli cultures were injected at 1.0 ml/min with 50 mm KPO4, 150 mm NaCl, pH 7.5, as running buffer. Fractions were collected (2 ml) and subjected to Western blotting with anti-human IVD antibody. A standard curve for this column was generated with the molecular mass standards listed above. Arabidopsis IVD in the tryptophan-inducible plasmid pAL-781 was a kind gift of Stefan Binder (12Daschner K. Couee I. Binder S. Plant Physiol. 2001; 126: 601-612Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar). Western Blotting—Twenty-five μg of protein from wild-type and mutant human IVD E. coli crude cellular extracts were subjected to electrophoresis on a 10% SDS-polyacrylamide gel. Separated proteins were transferred to 0.2 μm of Optitran™ nitrocellulose membrane (Schleicher & Schuell) using a TE Series Transphore electrophoresis unit (Hoefer Scientific Instruments, San Francisco, CA). IVD protein was detected by incubation with a 1:1,000 dilution of anti-IVD antibody followed by a 1:3,000 dilution of alkaline phosphatase-conjugated goat anti-rabbit IgG and visualization with a nitro blue tetrazolium/5-bromo-4-chloro-3-indolyl phosphate color development solution according to the manufacturer's instructions (Bio-Rad). Molecular Modeling—Computer modeling of St-IVD1 and St-IVD2 gene products and human SBCAD were performed using a Silicon Graphics O2 work station (Mountain View, CA) and the Insight II software package as described previously (14Mohsen A.W. Navarette B. Vockley J. Mol. Genet. Metab. 2001; 73: 126-137Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). The atomic coordinates of human IVD (Protein Data Bank code 1IVH) and rat short-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (Protein Data Bank code 1JQI) were used as reference molecules (21Tiffany K.A. Roberts D.L. Wang M. Paschke R. Mohsen A.W. Vockley J. Kim J.J. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 8455-8464Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar, 22Battaile K.P. Molin-Case J. Paschke R. Wang M. Bennett D. Vockley J. Kim J.J. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 12200-12207Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). The CoA-persulfide in the human IVD structure and the acetoacetyl-CoA in the rat short-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase structure were fixed as part of their respective structures prior to modeling. In each case, several models were generated and inspected manually for violations at the active site region and models with significant violations were rejected. Expression and Purification of Recombinant St-IVD1 and St-IVD2 Gene Products—The gene product of St-IVD2 (potato IVD) was successfully expressed using pKK223-3, the prokaryotic expression vector we previously employed for the production of human and C. elegans IVDs (14Mohsen A.W. Navarette B. Vockley J. Mol. Genet. Metab. 2001; 73: 126-137Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar, 17Mohsen A.W. Vockley J. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 10146-10152Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar). However, no St-IVD1 gene product was detectable by immunoblot in crude cellular extract from isopropyl 1-thio-β-d-galactopyranoside-induced cells containing the St-IVD1 cDNA in pKK223-3. Therefore, the tryptophan-inducible PL expression system, which provides tighter control over expression than the pKK223-3 vector, was used to express this protein. Both proteins were purified to greater than 90% homogeneity (Fig. 1A) and thus are the first recombinant plant ACDs to be purified. Spectral assays performed on the purified enzymes showed no indication of bound CoA-persulfide in the St-IVD1 gene product, whereas the St-IVD2 gene product had a red shift of the 445-nm absorbance peak to 432 nm, which is consistent with the presence of a CoA-persulfide molecule (Fig. 1B). The St-IVD2 gene product was “degreened” with sodium hydrosulfite before use in enzyme assays (14Mohsen A.W. Navarette B. Vockley J. Mol. Genet. Metab. 2001; 73: 126-137Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar, 18Williamson G. Engel P.C. Mizzer J.P. Thorpe C. Massey V. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 4314-4320Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Molecular Mass of the St-IVD1 and St-IVD2 Gene Products— Partially purified native potato IVD was previously reported to be a dimer of 85–90 kDa as was recombinant Arabidopsis IVD from an E. coli crude cellular extract (12Daschner K. Couee I. Binder S. Plant Physiol. 2001; 126: 601-612Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar, 13Faivre-Nitschke S.E. Couee I. Vermel M. Grienenberger J.M. Gualberto J.M. Eur. J. Biochem. 2001; 268: 1332-1339Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar). In the present experiments, the apparent molecular masses were estimated to be 188 and 146 kDa for the purified St-IVD1 and St-IVD2 gene products, respectively, using high pressure liquid chromatography gel filtration (Fig. 2). Purified human IVD also eluted at a volume corresponding to 146 kDa (data not shown). These data are consistent with the recombinant St-IVD1 and St-IVD2 gene products having a tetrameric quaternary structure. Likewise, the cellular extracts from isopropyl 1-thio-β-d-galactopyranoside-induced cells containing either the St-IVD2 gene product or Arabidopsis IVD were analyzed by fast protein liquid chromatography using a Superdex 200 size-exclusion column and the fractions were subjected to Western blotting with anti-IVD antibodies. IVD-reactive protein appeared only in fractions in the size range of 160–220 kDa for both proteins (data not shown). Substrate Specificity and Kinetic Constants of Recombinant St-IVD1 and St-IVD2 Gene Products—Enzyme activity was measured for the purified St-IVD1 and St-IVD2 gene products with a variety of acyl-CoA substrates using the anaerobic ETF fluorescence reduction assay. The two proteins had very different patterns of substrate utilization. Despite high homology to IVD, the St-IVD1 gene product had little or no activity with isovaleryl-CoA as substrate with a preference instead for 2-methylbutyryl-CoA (Fig. 3A). The K m was 1.0 μm with 2-methylbutyryl-CoA (Table I). Thus, we designated this enzyme as 2-methylbutyryl-CoA dehydrogenase (2MBCD). Potato 2MBCD had no detectable activity with isobutryryl-CoA (data not shown) but had minor activity with the straight-chain substrates, butyryl-CoA, valeryl-CoA, hexanoyl-CoA, and octanoyl-CoA, ∼20% or less than that seen with 2-methylbutyryl-CoA (Fig. 3A).Table IKinetic parameters of IVD and 2MBCD with preferred substratesEnzymePreferred substrateKmVmaxKcat per tetramerCatalytic efficiencyμmμmol/mins-1μm-1·s-12MBCD2-Methylbutyryl-CoA1.00.591.771.79IVDIsovaleryl-CoA1.31.250.980.73 Open table in a new tab As previously reported for the native protein, isovaleryl-CoA was the preferred substrate for recombinant St-IVD2 (Fig. 3A). However, purified recombinant potato IVD differed from the partially pure native form in that it showed no activity with isobutyryl-CoA as substrate using either the natural electron acceptor ETF or the chemical electron acceptor ferricenium (data not shown). The activity with 2-methylbutyryl-CoA was 5% of that seen with isovaleryl-CoA. Similar to previous results with recombinant human and C. elegans IVD (14Mohsen A.W. Navarette B. Vockley J. Mol. Genet. Metab. 2001; 73: 126-137Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar, 17Mohsen A.W. Vockley J. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 10146-10152Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar), potato IVD showed low activity with the straight-chain substrates butyryl-CoA, valeryl-CoA, hexanoyl-CoA, and octanoyl-CoA (Fig. 3A). Kinetic parameters were determined for the preferred substrate, isovaleryl-CoA. The K m was estimated at 1.3 μm (Table I), similar to the K m of human IVD for isovaleryl-CoA (17Mohsen A.W. Vockley J. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 10146-10152Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar). Mutagenesis of Human IVD—Five residues in the active site of 2MBCD differ from those found in all of the known IVD sequences (Val-88, Val-92, Val-96, Met-361, and Ala-365). To test whether these five amino acids play a role in determining the specificity toward isovaleryl-CoA versus 2-methylbutyryl-CoA, human IVD was mutated to match the 2MBCD sequence at the homologous residues Leu-95, Aal-99, Leu-103, Leu-370, and Gly-374. The quintuple mutant human IVD L95V/A99V/L103V/L370M/G374A was expressed in E. coli to a similar level as wild-type human IVD (Fig. 4) but was inactive with isovaleryl-CoA as substrate as indicated by assay of crude cellular extract using the ETF fluorescence reduction assay (Table II). Low activity was observed with 2-methylbutyryl-CoA as substrate. The quintuple mutant enzyme was unstable and became inactive during purification because of a loss of the FAD cofactor, hampering further enzymatic characterization.Table IISpecific activities (milliunits/mg) of human IVD substrate pocket mutants All of the data represent the mean ± S.D. for enzyme activity assays performed in triplicate. ND, not detectable.SubstrateWild typeL95V/A99V/L103VL370M/G374AL95V/A99V/L103VL370M/G374AIsovaleryl-CoA75.4 ± 11.4 (100%)NDND37.1 ± 1.6 (100%)2-Methylbutyryl-CoA4.3 ± 0.4 (5.7%)0.30 ± 0.07ND1.1 ± 0.02 (3.0%)Butyryl-CoA15.2 ± 0.2 (20.2%)NDND11.4 ± 1.5 (30.7%)Valeryl-CoA36.4 ± 1.9 (48.3%)NDND23.9 ± 1.7 (64.4%) Open table in a new tab The five mutations at human IVD residues 95, 99, 103, 370, and 374 were divided into two groups based on their position in the active site. A triple mutant L95V/A99V/L103V human IVD and a double mutant L370M/G374A human IVD (matching the homologous St-IVD1 residues) were made and tested for substrate specificity. Both mutants were expressed to similar levels as wild type human IVD in E. coli (Fig. 5). The L95V/A99V/L103V mutations, which line the bottom of the substrate pocket, eliminated activity with isovaleryl-CoA (Table II); however, activity was also undetectable with 2-methylbutyryl-CoA. The L370M and G374A mutations were predicted to accommodate the C2 branch of 2-methylbutyryl-CoA. Mutant L370M/G374A had reduced specific activities for all of the substrates compared with wild-type IVD, but overall, the substrate specificity profile was similar to wild-type human IVD (Table II). These two mutations did not enhance activity with 2-methylbutyryl-CoA as substrate. The two potato cDNA sequences St-IVD1 and St-IVD2 were successfully expressed in E. coli, and the substrate specificity of the corresponding purified recombinant enzymes was determined. Potato 2MBCD, the St-IVD1 gene product, demonstrated highest specificity for 2-methylbutyryl-CoA and no activity toward isovaleryl-CoA despite being 84% identical to potato IVD (the St-IVD2 gene product) and 65% to human IVD at the amino acid level (calculated without the mitochondrial leader sequences). Although structurally homologous to IVD, potato 2MBCD is functionally analogous to the human enzyme SBCAD. Potato 2MBCD and human SBCAD both have maximal activity with 2-methylbutyryl-CoA, although human SBCAD also shows high activity with other short straight-chain acyl-CoAs (23Rozen R. Vockley J. Zhou L. Milos R. Willard J. Fu K. Vicanek C. Low-Nang L. Torban E. Fournier B. Genomics. 1994; 24: 280-287Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar, 24He M. Burghardt T.P. Vockley J. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 37974-37986Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). SBCAD and potato 2MBCD, which are only 35% homologous at the amino acid level, represent an example of convergent evolution leading to the independent appearance of two enzymes (SBCAD and 2MBCD) specific for 2-methylbutyryl-CoA. It seems likely that the inappropriately designated St-IVD1 gene diverged from the potato IVD gene (St-IVD2) relatively recently, because data base searches failed to reveal similar gene duplications in other plant species. In 2MBCD, the IVD active site was adapted for efficient use of 2-methylbutyryl-CoA with surprisingly few amino acid substitutions, given the much larger sequence differences between mammalian IVDs and SBCADs. A sequence comparison of 2MBCD to known IVDs suggests that five differences in the active site (Table III) are responsible for the conversion to 2-methylbutyryl-CoA substrate specificity. Molecular modeling was used to compare the active site of 2MBCD to that of human SBCAD. A model of 2MBCD was created using the atomic coordinates of human IVD, and a model of human SBCAD was made using rat short-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase as a reference molecule. Fig. 5 shows the five 2MBCD residues in question superimposed upon the homologous residues in human SBCAD. Potato 2MBCD residues Val-88, Val-92, and Val-96 appear to provide binding for the distal C4 methyl of 2-methylbutyryl-CoA. The presence of a valine at 2MBCD position 88 appears to provide the space required for the longer and bulkier side chain of Met-361. The sulfur and distal methyl of Met-361 became juxtaposed to the dimethylbenzene ring of the flavin, partially filling the space where the aromatic ring of Tyr-380 lies in human SBCAD. Together, Met-361 and Ala-365 appear to fill the role of Tyr-380 by creating a binding site for the methyl branch linked to C2 of the 2-methylbutyryl-CoA. The sulfur and distal methyl group of Met-361 also serves to exclude the binding of isovaleryl-CoA by eliminating the space required to fit a substrate with a methyl group linked to C3.Table IIIResidues forming the active site of potato 2MBCD and the equivalent positions in potato IVD, human IVD, and human SBCADPotato 2MBCDaActive site three-dimensional structures with the exception of human IVD are predicted from models extrapolated from other known ACD X-ray crystal structures using the Insight II Modeler software. Potato 2MBCD residues that vary from known IVDs are in boldfaceb Catalytic base Open table in a new tab Site-directed mutagenesis was also used to study the role of the five 2MBCD active site residues (Table III and Fig. 5) in determining substrate specificity. The L95V/A99V/L103V/L370M/G374A substitutions in human IVD significantly altered the substrate specificity of the recombinant enzyme compared with wild type, leading instead to the pattern observed in potato 2MBCD, albeit with a lower level of activity. This is probably because of subtle conformational effects of amino acid residues at other positions outside the substrate binding pocket, such that, in 2MBCD, the conformation of the flavin moiety of FAD, the catalytic base, and/or other residues relative to the substrate are optimized. Based on molecular modeling of the 2MBCD active site, we predicted that mutating the residues homologous to Met-361 and Ala-365 in human IVD (Leu-370 and Gly-374) would eliminate the binding of isovaleryl-CoA. The specific activity of the L370M/G374A human IVD mutant with isovaleryl-CoA was, in fact, reduced but not eliminated compared with wild type IVD (Table II). In contrast, a triple mutant (L95V/A99V/L103V) of the three residues believed to be responsible for binding the distal end of the substrate in 2MBCD did completely eliminate activity with isovaleryl-CoA. However, activity with 2-methylbutyryl-CoA was also lost. Thus, whereas the residues at positions 370/374 may create the necessary cavity around the catalytic base for the C2 branch, the substitutions at the bottom of the pocket are critical to allow utilization of 2-methylbutyryl-CoA. These results imply that all five residues are needed to provide the proper fit and alignment of 2-methylbutyrl-CoA in the active site. The existence of a potato ACD with high specificity for 2-methylbutyryl-CoA suggests that isoleucine degradation is localized to mitochondria in at least some plants. However, BLAST searches of the DNA databases failed to identify any potential 2MBCD or SBCAD-like enzymes in other plants. To date, little is known regarding either isoleucine or valine degradation in plants. Whereas partially purified potato IVD and Arabidopsis IVD were reported to have activity with isobutyryl-CoA and thus potentially play a role in valine catabolism, our previous studies with native pea plant IVD (25Reinard T. Janke V. Willard J. Buck F. Jacobsen H.J. Vockley J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 33738-33743Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar) and our current studies with purified recombinant potato ACDs found no detectable enzyme activity with isobutyryl-CoA as substrate. Human and C. elegans IVDs also do not show activity with isobutyryl-CoA (14Mohsen A.W. Navarette B. Vockley J. Mol. Genet. Metab. 2001; 73: 126-137Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar, 17Mohsen A.W. Vockley J. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 10146-10152Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar). We conclude that neither potato IVD nor potato 2MBCD plays a role in valine catabolism. A recent analysis of the mitochondrial proteome of Arabidopsis revealed the presence of all of the enzymes required for leucine catabolism, including ETF, but only the enzymes that catalyze the final step of isoleucine and valine catabolism (26Taylor N.L. Heazlewood J.L. Day D.A. Millar A.H. Plant Physiol. 2004; 134: 838-848Crossref PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar). Zolman et al. (27Zolman B.K. Monroe-Augustus M. Thompson B. Hawes J.W. Krukenberg K.A. Matsuda S.P. Bartel B. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 31037-31046Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar) and Lange et al. (28Lange P.R. Eastmond P.J. Madagan K. Graham I.A. FEBS Lett. 2004; 571: 147-153Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar) have provided evidence for the existence of valine-catabolizing enzymes in plant peroxisomes. Thus, valine may be either partially or fully oxidized in peroxisomes, perhaps by an acyl-CoA oxidase. These have not been fully characterized for activity with branched-chain substrates. In this work, we have cloned, expressed, purified, and characterized potato IVD and a new enzyme, which we have designated potato 2MBCD. With its high homology to IVD, potato 2MBCD has provided an opportunity to further our understanding of the amino acids critical for IVD substrate specificity. On another level, 2MBCD provides an interesting example of convergent evolution and raises questions regarding the existence of a mitochondrial isoleucine degradation pathway in plants.

The consequences of mutations Ile265 → Ala, Thr267 → Ala, Gly271 → Ala, and Gly274 → Ala for the partial reaction steps of the Na+,K+-ATPase transport cycle were analyzed. The mutated residues are part of the long loop (“A-M3 linker”) connecting the cytoplasmic A-domain with transmembrane segment M3. It was found that mutation Ile265 → Ala displaces the E1-E2 and E1P-E2P equilibria in favor of E1/E1P, whereas mutations Thr267 → Ala, Gly271 → Ala, and Gly274 → Ala displace these conformational equilibria in favor of E2/E2P. The mutations affect both the rearrangement of the cytoplasmic domains (seen by changes in phosphoenzyme properties and apparent ATP/vanadate affinities) and the membrane sector (indicated by change in K+/Rb+ deocclusion rate). Destabilization of E2/E2P in Ile265 → Ala, as well as a direct effect on the intrinsic affinity of the E2 form for vanadate, may be explained on the basis of the E2 crystal structures of the Ca2+-ATPase, showing interaction of the equivalent isoleucine with conserved residues near the catalytic region of the P-domain. The rate of phosphorylation from ATP was unaffected in Ile265 → Ala, indicating a lack of interference with the catalytic function in E1/E1P. The effects of mutations Thr267 → Ala, Gly271 → Ala, and Gly274 → Ala provide the first evidence in the literature of a relative stabilization of E2/E2P resulting from perturbation of the A-M3 linker region. These mutations may lead to increased strain of the A-M3 linker in E1/E1P, increased stability of the A3 helix of the A-M3 linker in E2/E2P, and/or a change of the orientation of the A3 helix, facilitating its interaction with the P-domain. The transmembrane part is linked to a cytoplasmic head piece made up by three domains, denoted A- (actuator), N- (nucleotide-binding), and P- (phosphorylation) domains in the terminology based on the high resolution crystal structure of the closely related Ca2+-ATPase (2Kaplan J.H. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 2002; 71: 511-535Crossref PubMed Scopus (857) Google Scholar, 5Sweadner K.J. Donnet C. Biochem. J. 2001; 356: 685-704Crossref PubMed Scopus (178) Google Scholar, 11Toyoshima C. Nakasako M. Nomura H. Ogawa H. Nature. 2000; 405: 647-655Crossref PubMed Scopus (1594) Google Scholar). The A-domain consists of the N-terminal portion of the polypeptide chain in addition to the loop between M2 and M3, whereas the N- and P-domains are composed of the loop between M4 and M5 with the N-domain being inserted into the P-domain (11Toyoshima C. Nakasako M. Nomura H. Ogawa H. Nature. 2000; 405: 647-655Crossref PubMed Scopus (1594) Google Scholar). Comparing the atomic structures of the Ca2+-ATPase in Ca2+-bound E1 forms (E1(Ca2)) (11Toyoshima C. Nakasako M. Nomura H. Ogawa H. Nature. 2000; 405: 647-655Crossref PubMed Scopus (1594) Google Scholar) and E1(Ca2)·Mg·AlF4·ADP (12Sorensen T.L.-M. Moller J.V. Nissen P. Science. 2004; 304: 1672-1675Crossref PubMed Scopus (369) Google Scholar)) with those of the Ca2+-free E2 forms stabilized by thapsigargin (E2(TG)) (13Toyoshima C. Nomura H. Nature. 2002; 418: 605-611Crossref PubMed Scopus (796) Google Scholar) and E2(TG)·Mg·MgF4 (14Toyoshima C. Nomura H. Tsuda T. Nature. 2004; 432: 361-368Crossref PubMed Scopus (378) Google Scholar)), it appears that the cytoplasmic domains undergo large rearrangements in relation to the E1-E2 conformational changes, and a key event in active transport may be the extensive rotation of the A-domain parallel to the membrane. Because the A-domain is linked to the transmembrane domain through long cytoplasmic extensions of M1, M2, and M3, it is likely that these linker segments play critical roles in rotation of the A-domain and are essential for the interaction of the A-domain with the P-domain, with concomitant positioning of the conserved A-domain motif 214TGES217 in the vicinity of the catalytic site (15Patchornik G. Goldshleger R. Karlish S.J.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 11954-11959Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar, 16Toustrup-Jensen M. Vilsen B. J. Biol. A. 2004; 101: 2776-2781Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar) and long range communication with the ion binding sites in the membrane. Long before the appearance of the Ca2+-ATPase crystal structures, proteolytic cleavage experiments with Na+,K+-ATPase had demonstrated that cleavage sites in the cytoplasmic extension linking M3 to the A-domain (“A-M3 linker”) are alternately exposed in relation to the E1-E2 and E1P-E2P conformational transitions. Functional characterization of the chymotrypsin cleaved enzyme showed a block of the translocation of Na+, due to stabilization of the E1P(Na3) intermediate (18Jørgensen P.L. Petersen J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1985; 821: 319-333Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar, 19Jørgensen P.L. Andersen J.P. J. Membr. Biol. 1988; 103: 95-120Crossref PubMed Scopus (269) Google Scholar). Proteolytic cleavage in the corresponding region of the Ca2+-ATPase with excision of a small five amino acids sequence (239MAATE243) likewise seems to affect the conformational changes (20Moller J.V. Lenoir G. Marchand C. Montigny C. le Maire M. Toyoshima C. Juul B.S. Champeil P. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 38647-38659Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (60) Google Scholar). The cleaved enzyme retained the ability to bind Ca2+ and react with ATP, but the transition from E1P to E2P was blocked (20Moller J.V. Lenoir G. Marchand C. Montigny C. le Maire M. Toyoshima C. Juul B.S. Champeil P. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 38647-38659Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (60) Google Scholar). The functional consequences of mutation in the Na+,K+-ATPase of Gly263 next to the proteolytic cleavage point, or mutation of the homologous counterpart, Gly233, in the Ca2+-ATPase, are consistent with effects on the E1-E2 and E1P-E2P conformational equilibria (21Toustrup-Jensen M. Hauge M. Vilsen B. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 5521-5532Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar, 22Andersen J.P. Vilsen B. Leberer E. MacLennan D.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 21018-21023Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). It is therefore very interesting that the crystal structures of the Ca2+-ATPase show large structural differences in this region. In the E2 forms (13Toyoshima C. Nomura H. Nature. 2002; 418: 605-611Crossref PubMed Scopus (796) Google Scholar, 14Toyoshima C. Nomura H. Tsuda T. Nature. 2004; 432: 361-368Crossref PubMed Scopus (378) Google Scholar), the whole region connecting domain A with M3 has moved from a peripheral to a more central position closer to domain P, and the rearrangements include the formation of an α-helix in the E2 form, involving residues immediately C-terminal to Gly233 (Gly263 of Na+,K+-ATPase). In this report we have investigated the functional consequences of mutation in this region further. Ile265, with its bulky hydrophobic side chain, and Thr267 were both replaced with alanine. To examine the role of the conformation of the peptide backbone, we furthermore replaced the two glycines Gly271 and Gly274 with alanine. Neither of the residues selected for the present study, or their equivalents in other P-type ATPases, have previously been studied by mutagenesis. The isoleucine is particularly well conserved, being present in Na+,K+-ATPases, sarco(endo)plasmic reticulum Ca2+-ATPases, and H+,K+-ATPases. To examine the functional importance of these residues in Na+,K+-ATPase, we have studied the effects of the mutations on the overall and partial reactions of the enzyme, using steady-state and transient kinetic measurements. Mutagenesis, Expression, and Enzyme Preparation—Site-directed mutagenesis of the ouabain-resistant rat α1-isoform of Na+, K+-ATPase was carried out by the Kunkel method (23Kunkel T.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1985; 85: 3314-3318Google Scholar) or by using the QuikChange site-directed mutagenesis kit (Stratagene) to introduce the desired mutations directly into full-length cDNA. The mutant or wild-type cDNA was expressed in COS-1 cells, using 5 μm ouabain in the growth medium to select stable transfectants, and a crude plasma membrane fraction was isolated from the cells and made leaky by treatment with sodium deoxycholate or alamethicin (8Vilsen B. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 1455-1463Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar, 24Vilsen B. FEBS Lett. 1992; 314: 301-307Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar, 25Toustrup-Jensen M. Vilsen B. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 38607-38617Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). Functional Analysis—To eliminate the contribution of the endogenous ouabain-sensitive COS-1 cell enzyme (∼10% of the total Na+,K+-ATPase content of the preparation), 10 μm ouabain was added to all assays except for the one in which the affinity for ouabain was determined by variation of the ouabain concentration. For the phosphorylation assays, the enzyme was moreover preincubated in the presence of ouabain. ATP hydrolysis was measured at 37 °C as described previously (24Vilsen B. FEBS Lett. 1992; 314: 301-307Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar, 25Toustrup-Jensen M. Vilsen B. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 38607-38617Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). The Na+,K+-ATPase activity associated with the expressed exogenous enzyme was calculated by subtracting the background ATPase activity measured at 10 mm ouabain from the ATPase activity measured at 10 μm ouabain. Studies of the Na+ dependence of steady-state phosphorylation from [γ-32P]ATP and the time course of dephosphorylation, as well as the determination of the active site concentration by phosphorylation in the presence of 150 mm NaCl and oligomycin (20 μg/ml) to inhibit dephosphorylation, were carried out at 0 °C (26Vilsen B. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 13312-13324Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar). Deocclusion of K+ or Rb+ was studied in phosphorylation experiments at 10 °C, following formation of K+- or Rb+-occluded enzyme at room temperature as described previously (21Toustrup-Jensen M. Hauge M. Vilsen B. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 5521-5532Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar, 27Vilsen B. Andersen J.P. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 10961-10971Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar, 28Vilsen B. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 11389-11400Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). Rapid kinetic phosphorylation experiments at 25 °C with enzyme present in the E1Na3 form were performed using a BioLogic quench-flow module according to the previously described “Protocol 1” (21Toustrup-Jensen M. Hauge M. Vilsen B. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 5521-5532Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar, 29Toustrup-Jensen M. Vilsen B. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 38653-38664Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). In all the above-described phosphorylation experiments, background phosphorylation was determined in the presence of 50 mm KCl without NaCl. To examine the vanadate affinity under equilibrium conditions, 10 μg of deoxycholate-treated plasma membranes was incubated at 20 °C for 30 min in 40 μl of medium containing 20 mm Tris (pH 7.5), 5 mm MgCl2, 1 mm EGTA, 10 μm ouabain, and the indicated concentration of orthovanadate. To promote accumulation of the enzyme in the E2 form, 8 mm RbCl was added to the medium during the incubation with vanadate. The samples were then cooled to 0 °C to prevent dissociation of bound vanadate (30Smith R.L. Zinn K. Cantley L.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1980; 255: 9852-9859Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and the enzyme fraction with no vanadate bound was determined by measuring the amount of phosphoenzyme formed during a 30-s incubation following the addition of 360 μl of ice-cold phosphorylation medium producing final concentrations of 50 mm NaCl, 50 mm choline chloride, 20 mm Tris (pH 7.5), 5 μm [γ-32P]ATP, 5 mm MgCl2, 1 mm EGTA, and 20 μg/ml oligomycin. The data were fitted by assuming a simple one-site binding model where only the enzyme fraction with no vanadate bound phosphorylates, EP=(EPmax−EP∞)⋅(1−[vanadate]/(K0.5+[vanadate]))+EP∞(Eq. 1) where EPmax is the phosphorylation level obtained in the absence of vanadate, and EP∞ is the phosphorylation level corresponding to infinite vanadate concentration. Data Analysis and Statistics—Data normalization, averaging, and nonlinear regression analysis were carried out as previously (21Toustrup-Jensen M. Hauge M. Vilsen B. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 5521-5532Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). The lines in the figures show the best fit to the complete set of normalized data, and the extracted parameters with standard errors are indicated in the tables. ATP and vanadate dependences of the ATPase activity and the Na+ dependence of phosphorylation were analyzed using the Hill equation. In the analysis of the ouabain dependence of ATPase activity, the ouabain-inhibited enzyme was represented by the sum of two Hill functions, one corresponding to the exogenous rat enzyme and one corresponding to the endogenous COS-1 cell Na+,K+-ATPase. The time course of K+ deocclusion was analyzed using the biphasic time function described previously (21Toustrup-Jensen M. Hauge M. Vilsen B. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 5521-5532Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar, 27Vilsen B. Andersen J.P. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 10961-10971Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar) in which the component corresponding to the rapid phase is at maximum from the beginning. The time dependence of phosphorylation of enzyme in the E1Na3 form was fitted by using a mono-exponential function, and the dephosphorylation time courses following chase with ATP or ADP were fitted by using a bi-exponential function. Expression, Ouabain Sensitivity, and Catalytic Turnover Rate—The amino acid substitutions Ile265 → Ala, Thr267 → Ala, Gly271 → Ala, and Gly274 → Ala were introduced into the ouabain-resistant rat kidney α1-isoform of the Na+,K+-ATPase, and the mutant enzymes were expressed in COS-1 cells as previously (8Vilsen B. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 1455-1463Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar, 24Vilsen B. FEBS Lett. 1992; 314: 301-307Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar, 25Toustrup-Jensen M. Vilsen B. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 38607-38617Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). As in our earlier studies, we used a culture medium containing 5 μm ouabain for selection of the stable COS-1 cell lines expressing the mutant α1 enzymes. This is feasible, provided the mutant enzyme is functional, because the rat kidney Na+,K+-ATPase is less sensitive to ouabain (K0.5 for ouabain inhibition > 100 μm, cf.Table I) than the endogenous COS-1 cell Na+,K+-ATPase (K0.5 0.3–0.8 μm) (24Vilsen B. FEBS Lett. 1992; 314: 301-307Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar, 25Toustrup-Jensen M. Vilsen B. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 38607-38617Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). For all mutants the Na+,K+-transport rate was high enough to support cell growth. The mutants were expressed to an active site concentration (determined by phosphorylation with oligomycin included to maximally stabilize the phosphoenzyme) similar to that determined for the wild-type Na+,K+-ATPase, ranging between 30 and 60 pmol/mg of total membrane protein. Open table in a new tab The ouabain concentration dependence of Na+,K+-ATPase activity showed that the K0.5 value for ouabain inhibition of mutants Thr267 → Ala, Gly271 → Ala, and Gly274 → Ala was very similar to that of the wild type, whereas mutant Ile265 → Ala displayed a 2.7-fold increased K0.5 value (Table I). To avoid any contribution from the endogenous COS-1 cell enzyme, all measurements of ATPase activity and phosphoenzyme described below were carried out in the presence of 10 μm ouabain. The catalytic turnover rate was calculated as the ratio between the maximum Na+,K+-ATPase activity (determined at 37 °C and saturating substrate concentrations) and the active site concentration. As seen in Table I, the catalytic turnover rate was reduced to 61% in mutant Ile265 → Ala, and to 80 and 86%, relative to wild type, in Thr267 → Ala and Gly271 → Ala, respectively, whereas it was wild type-like in Gly274 → Ala. ATP Dependence of Na+,K+-ATPase Activity—Fig. 1 shows results of experiments in which the ATP dependence of the Na+,K+-ATPase activity was studied. The K0.5 value for ATP extracted from the data is listed in Table I. Relative to the wild type, Ile265 → Ala exhibited a 5.3-fold increase of the apparent affinity for ATP (K0.5 reduced), whereas in mutants Thr267 → Ala, Gly271 → Ala, and Gly274 → Ala, the apparent affinity for ATP was reduced (K0.5 increased 1.1- to 1.6-fold). In the wild-type Na+,K+-ATPase, ATP binds to E2(K2) with low affinity, accelerating the rate-limiting transition between E2(K2) and E1Na3, cf.Scheme 1, boxed ATP (3Post R.L. Hegyvary C. Kume S. J. Biol. Chem. 1972; 247: 6530-6540Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 31Forbush III, B. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 11104-11115Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The finding that mutant Ile265 → Ala exhibits an increased apparent affinity for ATP in the activation of Na+,K+-ATPase activity, relative to wild type, may be explained by an acceleration of E2(K2) → E1Na3 induced by the mutation independently of ATP. Alternatively, the Ile265 → Ala mutation might increase the intrinsic affinity of the low affinity binding site on E2(K2) for ATP. For mutants Thr267 → Ala, Gly271 → Ala, and Gly274 → Ala, on the other hand, the data are consistent with either a stabilization of the K+-occluded intermediate, E2(K2), occurring independently of ATP, or a reduced intrinsic affinity of E2(K2) for ATP. K+Occlusion—From the data in Fig. 1 it can be calculated that an increase of ATP concentration from 10 μm to 3 mm enhances the turnover rate 37-fold in the wild type, whereas the enhancement is only 8.5-fold in Ile265 → Ala. At 10 μm ATP, the turnover rate is 230 and 606 min–1 for the wild type and Ile265 → Ala, respectively. At this low ATP concentration, K+ deocclusion, E2(K2) → E1 + 2K+, is rate-limiting for the overall ATPase reaction. Therefore, the increased turnover rate of Ile265 → Ala, relative to wild type, determined under these conditions suggests that the rate of K+ deocclusion is increased in the mutant. To examine the rate of K+ deocclusion directly, the previously described phosphorylation assay was applied (21Toustrup-Jensen M. Hauge M. Vilsen B. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 5521-5532Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar, 27Vilsen B. Andersen J.P. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 10961-10971Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar, 28Vilsen B. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 11389-11400Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). Briefly, the enzyme is equilibrated with K+ in the absence of Na+ and ATP to form E2(K2). The phosphorylation kinetics is then determined following initiation of the phosphorylation reaction by a 10-fold dilution of the enzyme in a solution containing 100 mm Na+ and 1 μm [γ-32P]ATP. Oligomycin is added just prior to phosphorylation to prevent decay of the phosphoenzyme. This procedure allows estimation of the level of E2(K2) initially present, as well as the rate constant for the K+ deocclusion reaction E2(K2) → E1 + 2K+. The data presented in Fig. 2 were analyzed by fitting a biphasic time function (21Toustrup-Jensen M. Hauge M. Vilsen B. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 5521-5532Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar, 27Vilsen B. Andersen J.P. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 10961-10971Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar), in which the ordinate intercept reflects the non-occluded enzyme pool ready to bind Na+ and phosphorylate immediately, whereas the exponential part (shown by the line in Fig. 2) corresponds to deocclusion of K+ from E2(K2). The fraction of enzyme initially present as E2(K2) equals 100% minus the ordinate intercept. The parameters determined by this procedure are listed in Table II for all mutants. As is seen in Fig. 2 (upper panel) and Table II, Ile265 → Ala differed significantly from the other mutants and wild type with respect to both the deocclusion rate (9-fold enhanced, relative to wild type) and the level of the K+-occluded intermediate initially present (65% versus 88% for wild type).
